intro: Chamaesyce stanfieldii, commonly known as the Stanfield's spurge, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are usually narrow and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are inconspicuous and often surrounded by modified leaves called bracts. Chamaesyce stanfieldii is adapted to survive in harsh conditions with minimal water requirements.
